facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 64 of 1951 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 64 of 1951.

facts.text: Appeal from High Court of Judicature at Allahabad judgment dated 16th April 1948 by Malik C.J. and Prasad J. in First Appeal No. 358 of 1943.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal from the Judgment and Decree dated the 16th April. 1948, of the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad  Malik C.J. and Prasad J.  in First Appeal No 358 of 1943

facts.text: High Court appeal arose from judgment dated 22nd February 1943 of Additional Civil Judge Benares in Original Suit No. 33 of 1938.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the ent and Decree dated the 22nd February, 1943, Judgment and Decree dated the 22nd February, 1943 of the Court of the Additional Civil Judge Benares, in Original Suit No. 33 of 1938.

facts.text: Preliminary mortgage decree passed on March 31, 1939 by Additional Civil Judge Banaras in O.S. No. 33 of 1938.

anchor.surface_text: amending the decree passed on March 31, 1939, by the Additional Civil Judge, Banaras, in O.S. No. 33 of 1938.

facts.text: Mortgage deed executed on June 22, 1922 by Madho Ram, Sita Ram, Jai Ram and Lakshman sons of Pandit Raja Ram Pant Sess mortgaging immovable properties to Damodarji son of Kamta Nathji owner of Kothi Joshi Shivanath Vishwanath for Rs. 8,000 advanced by cheque with interest at 12 annas per cent per mensem quarterly rests.

anchor.surface_text: By a mortgage deed executed on June 22, 1922, Madho Ram, Sita Ram, Jai Ram aud Lakshman, all sons of Pandit Raja Ram Pant Sess, mortgaged cer-tain immovable properties in favour of Damodarji, son of Kamta Nathji, owner of the Kothi Joshi Shivanath Vishwanath for the due repayment of the sum of Rs. 8,000 advanced on that date by a cheque together with interest thereon at 12 annas per cent per mensem with quar- terly rests.

facts.text: Second mortgage executed on July 28, 1931 by mortgagors and their sons over same properties to Kothi Kamta Nathji Vishwanathji for Rs. 3,000 advanced by cheque used to pay amount due under earlier mortgage to Damodarji.

anchor.surface_text: On July 28, 1931, the said mortgagors and their sons executed a mortgage over the same properties in favour of Kothi Kamta Nathji Vishwanathji for the due repayment of Rs. 3,000 with interest thereon at twelve annas per cent per mensem with quarterly rests. It is recited in the deed that the sum of Rs. 8,000 was advanced on this date by a cheque and that the amount was utilised in paying up the amount due under the earlier mortgage deed to Damodarji proprietor of Kothi Shivanath Vishwanath.

facts.text: Suit No. 33 of 1938 filed in May 1938 by Girjadharji son of Damodarji and Murlidharji minor son of Gangadharji (son of Damodarji) against mortgagors and sons for recovery of Rs. 9,477-2-0 principal and interest up to suit date plus further interest under 1931 mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: On May 1938, Girjadharji, son of Damodarji, and Murlidharji, minor son of Gangadharji who was another son of Damodarji, filed suit No. 33 of 1938 in the Court of the Additional Civil Judge, Banaras, against the mortgagors and their sons for the recovery Rs. 9,477-2-0 due as principal and interest up to date of suit and for further interest under the mortgage deed of July 28, 1931.

facts.text: Trial court by judgment dated March 31, 1939 held mortgagors were agriculturists under U.P. Agriculturists Relief Act 1934, scaled down amount to Rs. 9,497-14-1 and passed preliminary mortgage decree for sale.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court, by its judgment dated March 31, 1939, held that though Sita Ram was assessed to incometax for the year 1931-32, the amount of such in- companyetax did number exceed the amount of cess payable on the land held by him and companysequently the second proviso to section 2  2  did number apply to him and he was, therefore, an agriculturist and as the other mortgagors were also agricul- turists all of them were entitled to the benefits under the Act. Accordingly, after scaling down the interest, a sum of Rs. 9,497-14-1 was declared to be due for principal, interest and companyts up to March 31, 1939, and a preliminary mortgage decree for sale was passed in that suit.

facts.text: U.P. Debt Redemption Act No. XIII of 1940 came into force in 1940.

anchor.surface_text: In 1940 the U.P. Debt Redemption Act  No. XIII of 1940  came into force.

facts.text: Five judgment-debtors applied on April 11, 1942 under section 8 of U.P. Debt Redemption Act 1940 to Additional Civil Judge Banaras to ascertain amount due and amend 1939 decree.

anchor.surface_text: On April 11, 1942, five of the judgment- debtors made an application under section 8 of this Act before the Additional Civil Judge, Banaras, who passed the decree.

facts.text: Judgment-debtors claimed debt actually advanced in 1922, they were agriculturists, interest reduced, nothing outstanding after accounts from 1922.

anchor.surface_text: In the petition it was stated that the debt was actually advanced in 1922, that the petitioners were agri- culturists within the meaning of Act XIII of 1940, that the decreeholders can only get interest at the reduced rate of Rs. 4-8-0 per cent. per annum from 1922, and that after adjustment of accounts numberhing will be found ,outstanding against the petitioners.

facts.text: Decree-holders objected that judgment-debtors not agriculturists, joint Hindu family, Sita Ram paid income-tax, debt not a loan under Act.

anchor.surface_text: The decree-holders filed a petition of objection asserting, inter alia, that the petitioners were by numbermeans agriculturists, that they and the respond- ents Nos. 3 to 7 were members of a joint Hindu family at the time of the execution of the mortgage deed of July 28, 1931, that Sita Ram used to pay income-tax at the date of the mortgage in suit and paid even at the time of the applica- tion, that all the members of the petitioners family were number agriculturists within the meaning of the Act and were, therefore, number entitled to the benefits thereof, that the debt advanced under the mortgage deed of July 28, 1931, was number a loan as defined in the Act and, therefore, the Act did number apply.

facts.text: Decree-holders' pleader admitted all judgment-debtors except Sita Ram were agriculturists under 1940 Act.

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing of the application before the Additional Civil Judge, the learned pleader for the decree-holders admitted that with the exception of Sita Ram the remaining judgment-debtors were agriculturists under Act No. XIII of 1940

facts.text: Sita Ram was teacher in Harish Chandra Intermediate College Banaras since 1907, salary Rs. 90 per month in 1930.

anchor.surface_text: Sita Ram stated that since 1907 he had been a teacher in Harish Chandra Intermediate College of Banaras, that in 1930 his salary was Rs. 90 per month

facts.text: Income-tax first deducted from Sita Ram's salary in February 1932.

anchor.surface_text: that the first deduction of in- companye-tax from his salary was made in February 1932.

facts.text: Income-tax assessment form dated February 9, 1933 showed Sita Ram assessed Rs. 1-14-0 on Rs. 180 for year 1931-32.

anchor.surface_text: The income-tax assessment form filed during the trial of the mortgage suit and marked as exhibits is dated Febru- ary 9, 1933, and shows that on that date Sita Ram was as- sessed at Rs. 1-14-0 as income-tax on Rs. 180 for the year 1931-32.

facts.text: Additional Civil Judge by judgment February 22, 1943 held applicants agriculturists, loan under Act, reopened accounts from June 22, 1922, debt fully discharged, decree discharged.

anchor.surface_text: By his judgment delivered on February 22, 1943, the Additional Civil Judge found that Sita Ram was number assessed to income-tax either at the date of the application under section 8 or at the date of the mortgage of 1931 and, there- fore, held that the applicants were agriculturists and that the case related to a loan as defined in Act XIII of 1940. ... Re-opening the accounts from June 2, 1922, the learned Judge companycluded that the whole of the principal and interest payable accord- ing to the Act had been fully discharged

facts.text: High Court Division Bench by judgment April 16, 1948 dismissed decree-holders' appeal holding judgment-debtors agriculturists at date of suit.

anchor.surface_text: a Division Bench  B. Mallik, C.J. andBind Basni Prasad J.  by its judgment delivered on April 16, 1948, held that the question whether Sita Ram was or was number an agriculturist on July 28, 1931, was number material as it was number denied that all the judgment, debtors were agriculturists on the date of suit.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal on certificate under section 110 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: he decree-holders have number companye up on appeal before us on a certificate granted by the High Court under section 110 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Sita Ram not assessed to income-tax on July 28, 1931, was agriculturist on date of 1931 advance, all applicants agriculturists, entitled to Act benefits.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, at the date of the advance, i.e., on July 28, 1931, Sita Ram Whose salary was below Rs. 2,000 per annum was number only number actually assessed to in- companye-tax but was number even liable to such assessment. ... It companysequently follows that he was an agriculturist on all these dates. The other judgment-debtors were admittedly agriculturists. Therefore, the application under section 8 was made by persons who were all agriculturists

facts.text: Trial court held mortgagees in both 1922 and 1931 mortgages were same so far as judgment-debtors concerned.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court held as a fact that so far as the judgment-debtors were companycerned the mortgagees were the same in both the mortgages.

holdings.text: The judgment-debtors applicants were all agriculturists within the meaning of the U.P. Debt Redemption Act, 1940.

anchor.surface_text: The position therefore is that Sita Ram was number assessed to income-tax at the date of the advance in 1931 or on the due date under the deed, i.e., in July 1937, or on the date of suit in 1938 or on the date of the application under section 8 in 1942. It companysequently follows that he was an agriculturist on all these dates. The other judgment-debtors were admittedly agriculturists. Therefore, the application under section 8 was made by persons who were all agriculturists

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sita Ram's salary below taxable limit on July 28, 1931; first IT deduction February 1932, assessment 1933; not assessed or liable on relevant dates; others admitted.

holdings.text: The decree passed in suit No. 33 of 1938 is a decree to which the U.P. Debt Redemption Act, 1940 applies.

anchor.surface_text: The only question that remains is whether the amount was due under a decree to which the Act applies. Under section 2(6) of the Act the phrase decree to which this Act applies means a decree passed before or after the commencement of this Act in a suit to which this Act applies. Section 2(17) defines the phrase suit to which this Act applies as meaning any suit or proceeding relating to a loan.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Decree passed before Act's commencement in suit relating to a loan per s2(6), s2(17).

holdings.text: The decree was passed in a suit relating to a loan as defined under section 2(9) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The question then, arises was the decree under which the judgment-debtors applicants are liable passed in a suit relating to a loan ? Loan is thus defined in section 2(9). Loan means an advance in cash or kind made before the first day of June, 1940, recoverable from an agriculturist or a workman or from any such person and other persons jointly or from the property of an agriculturist or workman

holdings.reasoning_summary: 1931 mortgage advance recoverable from agriculturists; 'recoverable' refers to time when due.

holdings.text: The 1931 advance qualifies as a loan under section 2(9) even assuming the proviso requires the advance to be made to an agriculturist at the date of advance.

anchor.surface_text: Assuming, but without deciding, that the proviso to section 2(9) applies and that in order to be a loan it must be shown that the advance was made to one who, at the date of the advance, was an agriculturist as defined in section 2(3) of the Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assumes strict interpretation arguendo; still satisfied as borrowers were agriculturists on July 28, 1931.

holdings.text: Sita Ram was not assessed to income-tax on July 28, 1931 and did not cease to be an agriculturist.

anchor.surface_text: the question has yet to be answered, namely, had Sita Ram ceased to be an agriculturist by reason of clause (b) of the proviso to section 2(3), that is to say, by reason of his being assessed to income-tax on July 28, 1931. According to the evidence of Surai Mani Tripathi and Sita Ram income-tax was first deducted at the source in the month of February 1932 by the College authorities and the actual assessment was made on February 9, 1933.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence shows first IT deduction Feb 1932; salary below Rs 2000 threshold pre-1931 amendment; not liable or assessed.

holdings.text: Judgment-debtors entitled to benefit of the Act; courts below correct in amending decree and holding debt discharged.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the application under section 8 was made by persons who were all agriculturists and who were liable to pay under a decree to which the Act applies, i.e., under a decree passed in a suit relating to a loan as defined by section 2(9). The Courts below therefore, were right in their conclusion that the judgment-debtors applicants were entitled to the benefit of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All s8 prerequisites satisfied: agriculturists, pre-commencement decree relating to loan.

holdings.text: Trial court's finding that mortgagees were the same in 1922 and 1931 mortgages upheld; accounts correctly reopened from 1922.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court held as a fact that so far as the judgment-debtors were concerned the mortgagees were the same in both the mortgages.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Point not raised in decree-holders' objections; no evidence adduced; trial court fact-finding accepted.

precedents.citation: Ketki Kunwar v. Ram Saroop I.L.R. 1943 All. 35 A.I.R. 1942 All. 390 1942 A. J. 578

anchor.surface_text: the case was fully companyered by the Full Bench decision of that High Court in Ketki Kunwar v. Ram Saroop 1 . The High Court, therefore, dismissed the appeal on this point alone. The question whether the account should be reopened from 1922 or from 1931 was number raised by the decree-holders at all. he decree-holders have number companye up on appeal before us on a certificate granted by the High Court under section 110 of the Code of Civil Procedure. Sri G.N. Kunzru appearing in support of this appeal has strongly questioned the companyrectness of the Full Bench deci- sion relied on by the High Court and the interpretation put by the High Court on section 21 and section 2  9  of the Act. As we think this appeal can be decided on a simpler ground we do number companysider it necessary, on this occasion, to express any opinion on either of these questions which are by numbermeans free from doubt. I.L.R. 1943 All. 35 A.I.R. 1942 All. 390  1942  A. J. 578.

precedents.cited_proposition: by reason of section 21 the proviso to the definition of loan in section 2(9) of the Act had no application and it was not necessary to show that the borrowers were agriculturists at the date when the advance was made

Under section 2(6) of the Act the phrase decree to which this Act applies means a decree passed before or after the commencement of this Act in a suit to which this Act applies. Section 2(17) defines the phrase suit to which this Act applies as meaning any suit or proceeding relating to a loan.

the question has yet to be answered, namely, had Sita Ram ceased to be an agriculturist by reason of clause (b) of the proviso to section 2(3), that is to say, by reason of his being assessed to income-tax on July 28, 1931. According to the evidence of Surai Mani Tripathi and Sita Ram income-tax was first deducted at the source in the month of February 1932 by the College authorities and the actual assessment was made on February 9, 1933.

Therefore, the application under section 8 was made by persons who were all agriculturists and who were liable to pay under a decree to which the Act applies, i.e., under a decree passed in a suit relating to a loan as defined by section 2(9). The Courts below therefore, were right in their conclusion that the judgment-debtors applicants were entitled to the benefit of the Act.
